Hixie: are you at all interested in what the PFWG had to say (informally and tentatively) about your Last Call feedback on ARIA btw? I can't remember if I told you after the telecon
Hixie: or would you rather wait for their promised email on the topic?
i need either a satisfactory edit to their spec, or a satisfactory reply that convinces me that no edit is needed, or an unsatisfactory reply i can reply to
I can tell you what reply is likely coming
I agree that such informal info is not enough to act on
let me just say it instead of asking whether I should:

1) They already (tentatively) planned to make native element semantics "win" over ARIA semantics for everything but the role attribute; host languages could make conflicting states nonconforming, and in case of a conflict the native semantics win (so <input type="checkbox" checked aria-checked=false> will be presented as checked.
this is unpublished and not yet stated officially in a public forum
2) They were not planning to do this with role, but after my examples of nonsensical role combinations, such as <input type="radionbutton" role="combobox">, they agreed to reconsider this.
And to give some form of feedback on this soon, possibly privately.
Whether they will follow up with an actual public post or actual spec edits, I cannot say.
they also said that if there is a limit on what elements are allowed to have what roles, they would want to review that
k
well
until all that is something i can act on...
if they stated something about #1 on the record, and agreed as to #2 (that host languages can limit what roles apply to what elements), would you feel like that is something you can act on?
what i need to be able to act on something is the normative text
which forms of normative text would be satisfacotry: (a) a snippet in an informal reply; (b) an Editor's Draft including new text; (c) a published Working Draft containing the new text?
and is it ok if (b) is Member-only or otherwise not fully public?
(as long as you get to see it?)
member-only is fine
i mean, it's dumb, but it's just regular w3c-dumb, it doesn't prevent me from doing my work
what i need to be able to reference aria from html5 is the text that i'm going to be referencing, so i can make sure it makes sense
authoring and implementation conformance criteria
and host language hooks
same as with any other spec
I'm hoping that they give at least an informal reply soon
I believe Sam asked for one in "72 hours" on the conference call but I will be generous and assume that means business day hours
with that in hand, it's probably not hard to get it in an Editor's Draft in less than their projected 3-month timeline to reply at all
given the history of interaction, i expect their response to be a poetic reading of the revised spec during next week's teleconference
I will give Sam credit for pressing them to give some kind of response
let's see if it actually works
i'm really not in any rush
i don't think it's a problem if aria isn't in HTML5 LC
we can always add it in the next version, like half the other features in the spec
though i will be amused if we go to LC without ARIA given that the whole reason for ARIA's existence is that ARIA is something that can be done quickly instead of requiring the whole of HTML to rev
this particular feature is somewhat important because it's actively being implemented by user agents and validators
if it has to be held up for substantive technical reasons, fine, but it would be a shame for it to be held up solely by procedural BS

do you know about modernizr?

We've already been using that for abbr tags, since we also aim for accessibility.  I had a long discussion about whether or not adopting the HTML5 draft would be accessible, but he who knows about Section501 gave a positive review - actually most are excited about moving forward.
We don't use modernizr, but we've had support for browser and css-capability-based selectors for a while.
We actually have a serverside script that takes care of most of it, and it actually attaches the class to the html tag, which is okay to do in JS (not in static, I believe).

if you're targeting current browsers and assistive technologies, you should include skip links before your navigation
JonathanNeal: you can replace "<meta content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" http-equiv="Content-Type" />" with just <meta charset="utf-8">
since i think ATs don't yet support the <nav> element
JonathanNeal: also, it looks like your h1/h2/h3 shouldn't be in an hgroup
JonathanNeal: since the h1 is for the site and the h3 for the page, at least those two should be distinct
Hixie, I thought they should, could you tell me why you think they shouldn't?
JonathanNeal:  see http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#distinguishing-site-wide-headings-from-page-headings
other than that it looks good
Well, I want to be as perfectly implementing these technologies as possible.
So, are you suggesting that the h1 and h2 tags are okay, but the h3 tag should be distinct from the Company Title and Community Title?
eg, the h3 exists within a different <section> where it is the h1?
AFAIK, http://www.webaim.org/techniques/skipnav/ is the best article on skip links
mpilgrim, are you referring that link to me?
yes
JonathanNeal: i'm not sure exactly what the community title is
JonathanNeal: so it's hard to say exactly what should happen
JonathanNeal: but the h1 and the h3 are titling different things, so they shouldn't be in a gorup
mpilgrim, that's great, I love that.  We would need to use some kind of unique styling to hide those links from users without removoing them from screen-readers.

in your second html 5 prototype, you had a <nav> section. i'm saying that even if you're using the <nav> element, you need to include a "skip navigation" link before it, because current ATs don't support the <nav> element yet.
Typically, like for the company logo on the h1 tag, we use font-size:0,text-indent: 99999em; overflow: hidden; or something where it's not hidden to screen-readers but stylistically invisible.
the webaim article shows you how to hide them properly but make them appear for screenreader users *and* keyboard-only users
Well, we're using the nav section as the main site navigation.
see http://www.webaim.org/techniques/skipnav/#focus
We would probably attach #skip to a class so it could be re-used.
That's great.
yeah
a class is fine

Well, that gets complicated because our product is pretty big.
JonathanNeal: if so, then you want an h1 for the site, an h2 for the subsection, and an h3 for the page, none in an hgroup
JonathanNeal: since they would all be titling different things
http://www.liferay.com/ We're a portal.
JonathanNeal: the way to think about it is this -- if you were to put every single page into the same HTML file
JonathanNeal: would there be a single heading or multiple headings?
JonathanNeal: the answer is presumably you'd have one site header, and then one subsection header per subsection, and one page header per "page" in each section
Hixie, I completely understand what you mean by if you were to put every single page into the same html file.  At work, I describe multiple pages as paginated content.
JonathanNeal: so, <hgroup> is basically saying "there's only one header here"
That's how we won keeping h1 as the company name and not the page title, because if every page was one page then that would be the global title of them all.
right

What is currently <div id="wrapper"> would best be replaced with <section> or <article> in HTML5?  My assumption is <section> because it doesn't specifically intend the page to have any subject, it could be completely administration based.
<section> has certain implications so <div> is probably better
if something is in fact a section, it's good to use <section>
I think we should have an element for <div id=wrapper> / <div id=content> / <div id=main> though
othermaciej, not if it doesn't have a header
if its peers are <aside>, <nav>, <header>, etc
well, the thing is that the page does have a header.
I see
then per current spec, <div> would be correct, but it does seem useful to have an element for the main content
you typically want something like <header/> <content/> <footer/> but we do not have <content/>
http://pastebin.org/9577 - in this example I'm using section.  I know accessibility folks mentioned that I need a skip element in the nav
JonathanNeal, oh, for that markup you do not need id=wrapper at all
JonathanNeal, just style the body element
yeah, <div id="wrapper"> seems redundant
Well, what if the site needs to be a certain overall width and centered.
in general, one shouldn't use <section> unless the purpose is to get the outline algorithm effects that come with <section>
id="banner" could be <header>
id="navigation" could be <nav>
JonathanNeal, body { width:700px; margin:0 auto } ?
id="footer" could be <footer>
Right, I used section because I believed the meaning of the content to be <section>.
id="content-wrapper" should be the hypothetical "main content" element
But the <section> element meets the criteria of content, if it has meaning.
If it doesn't have meaning, then <div> already works perfectly.
dude, you can style the body element :)
I'm curious if the list of premises I sent to public-html turns out to be flawed

hsivonen: the text about <section> says "the section element is appropriate only if the element's contents would be listed explicitly in the document's outline", but on the other hand it says it's a "generic document or application section", and applications don't generally have outlines
othermaciej: hmm. "application section" has a bad spec smell
Can the header and footer elements be children of the body?
whether applications have "sections", it's hard for me to say
JonathanNeal: yes
don't we have <fieldset> for application "sections"?
Well, I can be very direct with it's application, Liferay Portal.  So, at that point we're talking about multiple applications per page many times.
hsivonen: <fieldset> implies some rendering behavior that is no longer considered a good idea for modern HI design
JonathanNeal: are you developing Liferay itself or are you developing a portal based on Liferay (just curious)
othermaciej: true
hsivonen, the front end of the portal, http://www.liferay.com/web/jonathan.neal/blog
hsivonen: you didn't comment directly on auto-generated title=

I want to be as true to the intent of html5 as possible.  The move to html as the doctype is already in core, but without taking advantage of the newer, proper usage then it's not the most meaningful switch.
hsivonen: I assume that was an oversight
move to html5*
(in your premises email)
othermaciej: Is autogenerated @title materially different from autogenerated @alt under ATAG 2?
hsivonen: I don't know
hsivonen: did you mean to imply that ATAG 2 has the same kind of requirement for title?
othermaciej: I meant to imply that to the extent @title is considered to be a text alternative, ATAG 2 restricts it the same way it restricts alt
I could be wrong, though
I think in HTML5, it is considered a substitute text description in light of proper text alternative being unavailable
I'm not saying what the spec says to do is a good idea necessarily, but I don't think you addressed it
othermaciej: I sent email addressing it now
ATAG 2.0 B.2.4 seems to allow a tool to suggest an autogenerated alt, as long as the author has the opportunity to accept, modify or reject it
so it would be superficially ATAG-compliant to pop up a dialog on every image drop suggesting some alt text with a default OK button
although I do not think this would lead to good usability for the tool, or good accessibility in the resulting context
othermaciej: yes. Hence "Most authors don't respond to prompts in a meaningful way."
it would probably be completely off the table for a tool like Word where producing HTML is a side feature and not the main focus
It seems I forgot to add yet one more point
but it's such a given that I don't send more email now
hsivonen, what do you do?
the point being that the goal is to make average accessibility over the Web better--not just to comply with the letter of ATAG 2
ATAG 2.0 does require allowing the author to reject, so on its terms, it has to be possible to use an authoring tool to create output with no alternative text
JonathanNeal: I develop an HTML5 parser for Gecko, an HTML5 validator, and I read and write a lot of related email
hsivonen, well that's excellent!
Most of us are big fans of HTML5 and want to do it right, and the thumbs up has been given to make the move.
Minus the part where we wait for it to be final, you know, cause it's like after the second coming.
hsivonen: sent reply in email
hsivonen: I think the way HTML5 suggests using title does not technically run afoul of the letter ATAG2, even if a tool added it automatically, but I am not sure if it is in the spirit of ATAG2

annevk42, I agree with killing the wrapper div, I think we were using it when really the css margin style could have been safely set on the body tag, and also, when anything tricky needs to be made, we can still add <div> elements, but there's no reason to add a page-wide <section> when there's nothing outside of it and the body.

Also, I need to fix my improper usage of the hgroup tag, I even made a graphic to remind myself that the hgroup element should not group together tree-based hierarchies, but rather group together descriptive headlines.
JonathanNeal, because of bugs in IE5 and the somewhat special status of the body element lots of people do not realize it is just another <div>
JonathanNeal, i.e. you can give it a width, center it, etc.
Right, and I was testing all of this against ie6 too.
it should work fine in IE6 in standards mode
annevk42: doesn't <body> have some special behavior for backgrounds though?

Someone was asking if Liferay has an official "supported" list, and I'm not sure that we do, but I know that we support Internet Explorer 6+, Firefox 2+, and Safari 4+.  I know that I personally test everything on IE6+, FF3, and Safari 4.
othermaciej, only if nothing is set on html {}

othermaciej, but yeah, it has a somewhat special status, e.g. some event handler attributes on the body element register event handlers on the Window object
Yes, because Safari3 was never really tested to begin with.
JonathanNeal: I see

So, Nate is the director of UI and he works on a Mac now, which has probably made a significant impact on our Safari and Mac testing. :-)

Well, a lot of our support is directed by what the corporate clients are running, and sadly they're pretty-much all running IE6.
Whether it's government policy or MS built them a custom chop of IE6 that couldn't reasonably be afforded an upgrade.
IE6 has itself a solid little perch there

othermaciej, you could set html { overflow-y: scroll; } *for sure triggering the scrollbar* and body { background: *whatever color and whatever image*; margin: 100px auto 0; width: 960px; } and the background will still expand from the very top and all the way from either side of the page, in IE6+, FF, Safari.
However, if you set html { background: *anything* } then it will trigger the background to act like it would on a div.

jgraham, yes, but very early in my research.  All right, thanks.
